revision.text:
{{Infobox company |company_name = Code 42 Software |company_logo = [[File:Code42 CMYK.png|200px]] |company_type = Private |foundation = 2001 |location = [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, MN, USA]] |key_people = Matthew Dornquast, co-founder and CEO
Brian Bell, President and COO
Brian Bispala, co-founder and VP Engineering
Justin Grammens, co-founder and VP Engineering
Sam Schroeder, co-founder and VP Product Management
Mitch Coopet, co-founder and CrashPlan Product Manager |industry =Software |products = CrashPlan
CrashPlan+
CrashPlan PRO
CrashPlan PROe |website = {{URL|http://www.code42.com}} }} '''Code 42 Software Inc.''' is the developer of the CrashPlan [[backup software]] and services suite. It was founded in 2001 as an IT consultancy. Code 42 started a project to create a [[Facebook]]-like desktop application, but ended up focusing on the [[online file storage|online storage]] element, releasing CrashPlan in 2007. The company raised $52.5 million in 2012 as part of a fund by Accel Partners for big data companies. CrashPlan is sold to consumers on a [[freemium]] model, wherein local backups are free, but uploading to Code 42's servers is sold on a monthly subscription through CrashPlan+. There are also enterprise versions that are usually used to facilitate backups to the company's own servers. CrashPlan gets positive reviews based on its pricing, feature-set and user interface, but large, initial backups are slow. ==History== Code 42 was founded as an IT consulting company for businesses in 2001{{cite news|first=Kevin|last=Coss|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/print-edition/2011/04/15/cracking-the-code.html|publisher=BizJournals|title=Code 42 breaks into the B-to-B market|date=April 15, 2011|accessdate=October 1, 2012}}{{cite news|first=Todd|last=Nelson|newspaper=Star Tribune|title=Founder of data storage backup firm has a plan: Grow but stay put|date=May 16, 2011|pages=1D}} by Brian Bispala, Mitch Coopet and Matthew Dornquast.{{cite news|first=Dean|last=Takahashi|url=http://venturebeat.com/2012/01/17/code-42-software-raises-52-5m-to-raise-profile-for-online-backup/|publisher=VentureBeat|title=Code 42 Software raises $52.5M to raise profile for online backup|date=January 17, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012}} As a homage to [[Douglas Adams]], who died that year, the company name incorporates a reference to the ''[[Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy]]'', where the number 42 is the answer to "life, the universe and everything."{{cite news|first=Joseph|last=Kovar|newspaper=CRN|url=http://www.crn.com/news/storage/232500091/crashplan-cloud-storage-vendor-code-42-grabs-52-5-million-in-vc-funding.htm|title=CrashPlan Cloud Storage Vendor Code 42 Grabs $52.5 Million In VC Funding|date=January 18, 2012|accessdate=October 1, 2012}} Some of its first projects included a re-design of [[Sun Country Airlines]]’ website in 2002, a project for [[Target Corporation|Target]],{{cite news|first=Jeremy|last=Stratton|newspaper=The Minneapolis Post|url=http://www.minnpost.com/politics-policy/2011/08/lessons-code-42-software-innovator-matthew-dornquasts-tech-biz-wisdom|title=The Lessons of Code 42: Software innovator Matthew Dornquast's tech-biz wisdom|date=August 27, 2011|accessdate=October 1, 2012}} and the ticket booking engine for [[Midwest Airlines]]. Income from the IT services business was used to bootstrap different product ideas for six years.{{cite news|first=Stacey|last=Higginbotham|publisher=GigaOm|url=http://gigaom.com/2012/01/17/meet-code-42-accels-first-big-data-fund-investment/|title=Meet Code 42, Accel’s first Big Data Fund Investment|date=January 17, 2012|accessdate=October 1, 2012}} In 2006, the company planned to create a [[Facebook]]-like desktop application, but the project became too big and impractical. Code 42 focused on the online storage element of the application, creating CrashPlan in 2007. In June 2011, Code 42 acquired a Minneapolis-based mobile development company, Recursive Awesome LLC, to support its software on mobile devices. Recursive’s employees were moved to its Minneapolis headquarters.{{cite news|first=Ed|last=Stych|newspaper=Minneapolis Business Journal|title=Code 42 buys mobile app firm that works with Best Buy|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/news/2011/06/01/code-42-buys-mobile-app-firm-best-buy.html|date=June 1, 2011|accessdate=October 1, 2012}} Afterwards the company built a 10,000 square-foot expansion to its offices. In 2012, Code 42 raised $52.5 million in funding.{{cite news|first=Sarah|last=McBride|coauthors=Gary Hill|publisher=Reuters|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/technologyNews/idCATRE80H09T20120118|title=Carbonite rival Code 42 raises $52.5 million|date=January 18, 2012|accessdate=October 1, 2012}}{{cite news|first=Katharine|last=Grayson|newspaper=Minneapolis Business Journal|title=VC investment climbs higher|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/print-edition/2012/04/06/vc-investment-climbs-higher-in-q1-2012.html|date=April 6, 2012|accessdate=October 18, 2012}} The funding was the first distribution from a $100 million pool established in 2011 by [[Accel Partners]] to fund Big Data companies.{{cite news|first=Rebecca|last=Grant|publisher=VentureBeat|title=Origami Logic in process of folding up $8M in funding|date=September 20, 2012|url=http://venturebeat.com/2012/09/20/origami-logic-in-process-of-folding-up-8m-in-funding/|accessdate=October 1, 2012}} ==Business== As of April 2011, 80% of Code 42 Software’s revenue came from business customers, while the remainder comes from consumers and a small portion from service provider partners. Code 42 has been profitable each year since it was founded. Code 42 grew from $1.4 million in revenue in 2008 to $11.46 million in 2010 and $18.5 million in 2011.{{cite news|newspaper=Inc. Magazine|url=http://www.inc.com/inc5000/profile/code-42-software|title=Code 42 Software|year=2011|accessdate=October 18, 2012}} As of January 2012, the company has backed up 100 petabytes of data and processes 100 billion files a day. It had 4,500 business customers as of that September. ==CrashPlan== [[File:CrashPlan screenshot.png|thumb|300px|CrashPlan+ user interface]]CrashPlan backs up data to remote servers, other computers, or hard drives.{{cite news|first=Katie|last=Boehret|url=http://allthingsd.com/20120214/for-backup-youve-got-a-friend-family-or-cloud/|publisher=All Things D|title=For Backup, You've Got a Friend, Family or Cloud|date=February 14, 2012|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} It is available on [[Mac OS|Mac]], [[Windows]], [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] and [[Linux]].{{cite news|first=Brian|last=Nadel|url=http://review.techworld.com/storage/3335598/crashplan-review/|newspaper=Computerworld|title=CrashPlan review|date=February 8, 2012|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} The consumer version is sold on a freemium model, where daily local backups are free, but using Code 42's cloud service requires a paid subscription, called CrashPlan+.{{cite news|first=Ivan|url=http://www.informationweek.com/storage/reviews/online-storage-buyers-guide/225600381?pgno=2|last=Schneider|newspaper=InformationWeek|title=Online Storage Buyer's Guide|date=June 19, 2010|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} There is also an option to lease a hard drive, so a faster local backup can be performed to the drive and it can be shipped back to Code 42 for initial backup.{{cite news|first=Glenn|last=Fleishman|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/1142606/online_backup.html|publisher=Macworld|title=Online backup services|date=September 7, 2009|accessdate=October 19, 2012}}{{cite news|first=Corrina|last=Lawson|publisher=WIRED|url=http://www.wired.com/geekdad/2012/03/crashplan/|title=CrashPlan Saves Your Files in Multiple Places|date=March 31, 2012|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} Initial backups may take several hours over [[LAN]] or days over the internet, but afterwards, continuous and incremental backups are done without user intervention.{{cite news|first=Rafe|last=Needleman|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17939_109-9680560-2.html|publisher=CNET|title=Back up your mom with Crashplan|date=January 24, 2007|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} Data is encrypted{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/03/27/tech/real_technology/main4896328.shtml|title=How Safe Is Your Data In "The Cloud"?|date=April 3, 2009|accessdate=October 26, 2012|first=Rafe|last=Needleman}} and password-protected. There is also an option for a more secure private key. Corporate users have CrashPlan PROe back up to private servers instead of Code 42's data center in four out of five cases. The software has an option to create a private on-site backup server.{{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Cunningham|publisher=ArsTechnica|url=http://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2012/05/crashplan-is-cloud-backup-for-literally-everyone/|title=Hands-on with CrashPlan: cloud backup for all|date=May 18, 2012|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} ===Reception=== ''[[MacWorld]]'' gave CrashPlan a 4.5 out of 5,{{cite news|first=Leah|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/1166708/crashplan_reliable_cloud_backup_and_online_storage.html|last=Yamshon|publisher=Macworld|title=CrashPlan+: Reliable cloud backup and online storage|date=May 16, 2012|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} and [[Gartner]] gave the enterprise version, CrashPlan PROe, an "excellent" rating.{{cite news|title=Critical Capabilities for Enterprise Endpoint Backup|publisher=Gartner|url=http://www.gartner.com/DisplayDocument?id=2191815&ref=g_fromdoc|date=October 9, 2012|coauthors=Pushan Rinnen, Dave Russell and Alan Dayley|accessdate=October 25, 2012}} In benchmark tests by ''[[Computerworld]]'', CrashPlan was the best performer in an incremental backup of 25 MB, but the worst performer in archiving an entire system drive, which took almost five days. A ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' columnist also noted lengthy initial backups, followed by better-performing incremental ones. [[Techworld]] praised CrashPlan for its operating system support and configuration options. [[Ars Technica]] said CrashPlan had better features and pricing options than competitors. It also receives high marks in reviews for its user interface.{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Muchmore|url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2375988,00.asp|newspaper=PC Magazine|title=CrashPlan 3.0|date=January 20, 2011|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} The free consumer version does not allow users to recognize mapped drives, a feature offered by competitors; however, there is an unofficial workaround.{{cite news|publisher=CrashPlan Support|title=Back Up a Windows Mapped Drive|accessdate=October 24, 2012|url=http://support.crashplan.com/doku.php/recipe/back_up_windows_mapped_drives}} ==See also== * [[Comparison of online backup services]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.code42.com/ Official website] * [http://crashplan.com Official Site] * [http://support.crashplan.com/doku.php/faq/cpc Crashplan FAQ] [[Category:Companies based in Minneapolis, Minnesota]] [[Category:Software companies based in Minnesota]] [[Category:Backup software]] [[Category:Web hosting]] [[Category:Mac OS software]]
